date.headline: Genesis
date.text:
• Created in 10 days in May 1995 by Brendan Eich, then of Netscape.
  • A rush job, due to commercial pressure.

asset.media: "If I had done classes in JavaScript back in May 1995, I would have been told that it was too much like Java or that JavaScript was competing with Java ... I was under marketing orders to make it look like Java but not make it too big for its britches … [it] needed to be a silly little brother language."

date.headline: Influences
date.text:
• Based on Scheme (a Lisp dialect)
  • This led to JavaScript having closures
  • Also influenced by Self, which has prototypal inheritance
  • Syntax is taken from C

date.headline: What's in a name?
date.text:
• The original name in May 1995 was Mocha.
  • This changed in September 1995 to LiveScript.
  • In December 1995 Sun granted a trademark license for the term "Java" and so the name was changed again to JavaScript.
  • Java was very popular at the time, and it was hoped that JavaScript would ride the Java wave.

date.headline: Standardisation
date.text:
• In 1996 – 97 JavaScript was taken to ECMA (European Computer Manufacturers Association) for standardisation, so that browser vendors other than Netscape could produce implementations.
  • ECMAScript is the name given to the standard ECMA262-1, with JavaScript being the most popular implementation.
  • ActionScript 3 is another well known implementation of ECMAScript, but with extensions.

date.headline: Further standards
date.text:
• ECMAScript 2 was released in 1998.
  • ECMAScript 3 in 1999.
  • ECMAScript 3 is the baseline for modern JavaScript in the browser.
  • The original ES4 work started in 2000 and seemed to go well, with Microsoft even implementing some of the proposals in their JScript.NET language.

date.headline: ES4 grinds to a halt
date.text:
• It became clear after a while that Microsoft weren't going to implement standard ECMAScript in IE.
  • The .NET language also diverged.
  • By 2003, the original ES4 work was mothballed.

date.headline: ECMAScript 3.1 anyone?
date.text:
• Brendan Eich (now at Mozilla) started work on “E4X” (ECMA-357) in 2005.
  • He joined forces with Macromedia (later bought by Adobe) who were implementing E4X in Action Script 3.
  • Adobe released AVM2 (ActionScript VM) and ActionScript 3 but it was realised in 2007 / 8 that these would never converge with JavaScript.
  • At the same time, Douglas Crockford (then at Yahoo) joined forces with Microsoft to oppose ES4, and the ES3.1 effort was born.

date.headline: Ajax
date.text:
• In 2005, Jesse James Garrett released a white paper in which he coined the term Ajax (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML).
  • This allows JavaScript code to retrieve data from a server (rather than entire web pages) and update parts of a page, leading to more light weight and more responsive web pages.
  • This resulted in a renaissance for JavaScript, with the release of open source libraries such as Protoype, jQuery, Dojo and Mootools.

date.headline: ECMAScript 5
date.text:
• In July of 2008 the disparate parties on either side of the ECMAScript 4 schism came together in Oslo.
  • In early 2009 an agreement was reached to rename ES3.1 to ES5 and push the language forward using an agenda known as Harmony.

date.headline: Current hot topics
date.text:
• Google’s V8 JavaScript engine implements ECMAScript 5.
  • NodeJS is gaining popularity on the server side.
  • HTML5 includes many additional JavaScript APIs.
